boardgame.name: Picking Sides
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The game is based upon a novel (by the same author) and attempts to re-create the tone and setting of the novel, though the rules could easily be adapted to any setting. Magic in the system is elemental and all effects are tied to one of seven types of element: fire, water, earth, air, wood, metal, and spirit. Each element has a specific area in which it works best.

Characters have typical demographic data determined with narrative tags. Characters also have a flaw--either wrath, envy, gluttony, sloth, lust, greed, or pride. Characters select an element. Characters have seven Attributes (Agility, Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Belief, Manipulation, and Technology) among which the player distributes a total of 280 points from a pool. Characters may also have Skills which have another pool of 280 points distributed among them. Skills may improve with use. The game lists several sample Skills but it is up to the player to select whatever Skills their character should have.

Action resolution involves a d100 roll; "rolling under" a Skill or Attribute indicates success. The Game Master may modify the role (generally up to +/- 30) based on difficulty. Magic is handled under a separate system and depends upon the character's Level with the Element upon which the magic is based. Levels run 1-6 for characters, with 3 being typical. Under normal circumstances, a Level 1 magic use has a 50% chance to succeed, with each subsequent level boosting the chance by 10%.

boardgame.name: Pinion
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Pinion resolution uses 2d10 but a 1d20 variant is provided.

Characters have Primary Stats (Attributes) divided into Body (Strength, Prowess, Physique), Mind (Reason, Perception, Knowledge), and Spirit (Will, Sentience, Potency). Characters also have Derived Stats including Movement, Toughness, and Vitality. Primary Stats can be randomly determined or purchased form a point pool; humans have Primary Stats in the 1-20 range with a typical value being 6-7. Characters have Advantages and Disadvantages which can be purchased from the same point pool used for Primary Stats. Characters also have Skills with numeric ratings similar to Primary Stats. However, the Skill lists provided are examples only and the game Skill list will depend upon the "Interlock" (genre expansion module) being used.

Non-trivial tasks are resolved by rolling 2d10 and "rolling under" the appropriate Skill or Primary Stat. In opposed actions both opponents roll and the one with the greatest difference between their roll and Skill wins. In unopposed actions the roll must be lower than the Skill by some Task Difficulty established by the Lawgiver (Game Master). Combat is handled with an appropriate Skill (Shoot, Throw, Strike, Claw, Punch, Kick, Bite, or Fight) as an opposed action (usually by Dodge, Parry, or Block). Extended rules apply to rapid-fire firearms, multiple attacks, hand-to-hand attacks, and other special maneuvers.

boardgame.name: Doctor Who: Time of the Daleks
boardgame.description:
"Exterminate!" They muttered about their sacred hatred, the Oncoming Storm. Their creator had a plan, a plan to make the Daleks great again. A plan to turn all their defeats into victories. A plan to remove the one variable that has always interfered with the master plan. The Doctor must be erased from time itself!

Ever wanted to be the Doctor? Travel in time and space, meet companions and have adventures? In Doctor Who: Time of the Daleks you do just that, with every player picking a Doctor and trying to thwart the Daleks' master plan of erasing the Doctor from history. Do you have what it takes to fill a Time Lord's Shoes? Join us on an adventure in space and time with a game that is bigger on the inside...

Doctor Who: Time of the Daleks is a semi-cooperative board game that puts players in the roles of their favorite Doctor, pulled from various timelines to stop the Daleks: Either one player/doctor wins, or the Daleks win and all the players/doctors lose.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Pub Battles: Brandywine
boardgame.description:
Pub Battles: Brandywine is meant to be played out. It is rugged enough to withstand spilled drinks at your favorite café or restaurant. It is fast and simple: 1 hour play time and 1 page rules. The stunning Kriegspiel style hardwood blocks on a real commander’s style canvas map looks like the real thing.


Mini style movement.
Bucket of Dice style combat.
Formations move by random chit pull.
Leaders can alter the move sequence and rally pieces before combat.


Washington sets up first. The British can attack from either flank or the center, recreating the historical sense of surprise for the battle and providing great re-playability.

boardgame.name: High Octane
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

High Octane is a slightly more serious, possibly more complicated, and hopefully still fun expansion for Risus.

User summary:

The expansion lists numerous Clichés to use during character generation. In this expansion, Clichés have three components--a name, a number of dice, and a scope. For example: Psycho Killer, 4, Butchering people with household objects.

The document includes Swords & Sorcery genre notes as well as "bonus rules" for traps and spells. Also included are Science Fiction notes. Also included are a weapons list and optional rules for modern genre gaming. For the Game Master, some notes on NPCs and locations also are included.

boardgame.name: The Reverse RPG
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Revers RPG is a rules-light and lighthearted role-playing game where players don't get to decide what their characters do--but they do get to decide whether they succeed at doing it. Players grab a handful of mixed marbles (black, white, and a few red) and then as the Game Master outlines the narrative, characters determine success or failure by playing (discarding) either a white or black marble, respectively. Another player may then play a red marble to reverse the decision. Players don't get to grab another handful of marbles until they've played out the first handful--including red ones.

Character creation is exceptionally simple and involves defining Attributes and then arranging them across a dice number spread. When an action is taken, the player rolls a dice, finds the Attribute, and must proceed to resolve the situation in that manner (e.g., using that Attribute). The GM narrates the campaign; the players narrate the action scenes.

boardgame.name: Epitaph
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Epitaph is a campaign setting for the Fudge system. The setting does implement some variant rules and specific rules but they are fairly minor variations on the basic system.

The setting is heavily engaged with the history of the world and the cosmology. There are various geographical realms detailed as well, and power factions that span the globe. Generally speaking, the scope of the campaign is epic and the assumption is that characters will be fully developed and quite powerful during standard play.
